docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Kushi, a Japanese scholar who popularized the macrobiotic diet in the United States, helped to change the way health-conscious Americans eat.

headline.main: Michio Kushi, Advocate of Natural Foods in the U.S., Dies at 88
headline.print_headline: Michio Kushi, 88, Advocate of Natural Foods in the U.S.

docs.abstract: Michio Kushi, Japanese scholar who made macrobiotic diet popular in United States, helping change eating habits of health-conscious Americans, dies at age 88.
docs.snippet: Mr. Kushi, a Japanese scholar who popularized the macrobiotic diet in the United States, helped to change the way health-conscious Americans eat.

docs.lead_paragraph: I gave up Big Macs and started exercising. But I was neglecting my inner life.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Pico Iyer describes discovering benefits of pairing healthy diet and exercise with devotion to mental health; holds that allowing for quiet time has improved his inner life.
docs.snippet: I gave up Big Macs and started exercising. But I was neglecting my inner life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans remain in charge of the House, but it won't be the same Republicans leading many committees.

headline.main: New GOP Faces at the Helm of 9 House Committees
headline.print_headline: New GOP Faces at the Helm of 9 House Committees

docs.snippet: Republicans remain in charge of the House, but it won't be the same Republicans leading many committees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican senators poised to lead major committees when the GOP takes charge are intent on pushing back many of President Barack Obama's policies, setting up potential showdowns over environmental rules, financial regulations and national security.

headline.main: New GOP Senate Chairmen Aim to Undo Obama Policies
headline.print_headline: New GOP Senate Chairmen Aim to Undo Obama Policies

docs.snippet: Republican senators poised to lead major committees when the GOP takes charge are intent on pushing back many of President Barack Obama's policies, setting up potential showdowns over environmental rules, financial regulations and national security.

docs.lead_paragraph: The government issues dietary guidelines every five years to encourage Americans to eat healthier. This year's version may look at what is healthy for the environment, too.

headline.main: Guide for Healthy Eating May Consider Environment
headline.print_headline: Guide for Healthy Eating May Consider Environment

docs.snippet: The government issues dietary guidelines every five years to encourage Americans to eat healthier. This year's version may look at what is healthy for the environment, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the government has been issuing guidelines about healthy eating choices. Now, a panel that advises the Agriculture Department is ready to recommend that you be told not only what foods are better for your own health, but for the environment as well.

headline.main: New Diet Guidelines Might Reflect Environment Cost
headline.print_headline: New Diet Guidelines Might Reflect Environment Cost

docs.snippet: For years, the government has been issuing guidelines about healthy eating choices. Now, a panel that advises the Agriculture Department is ready to recommend that you be told not only what foods are better for your own health, but for the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic disagree on whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a standard therapy in developed countries.

headline.main: Ebola Doctors Are Divided on IV Therapy in Africa
headline.print_headline: Ebola Doctors Are Divided on IV Therapy in Africa

docs.abstract: Medical community is engaged in debate over use of intravenous hydration on patients infected by Ebola in West African countries, treatment that many attribute to the higher survival rate of patients treated in the West; debate comes at time when focus of aid efforts is shifting from stopping spread of disease, which seems to be under control, toward saving lives of those infected.
docs.snippet: Doctors seeking to stem the Ebola epidemic disagree on whether most patients in West Africa should, or can, be given intravenous hydration, a standard therapy in developed countries.
